title: Analysis of Functions with L Hospital and Squeeze

content.question: NO CALCULATOR IS ALLOWED FOR THIS QUESTION. Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit. Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point. Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for which <math alttext="f of x" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is a real number. Functions <math alttext="f" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="g" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="h" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> are twice-differentiable functions with <math alttext="g of 2, equals, h of 2, which equals 4" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mi>h</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. The line <math alttext="y equals, 4 plus, two thirds times, open parenthesis, x minus 2, close parenthesis" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>+</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></mfrac><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is tangent to both the graph of <math alttext="g" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> at <math alttext="x equals 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> and the graph of <math alttext="h" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> at <math alttext="x equals 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. a) Find <math alttext="h prime of 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>.

frqParts.text: NO CALCULATOR IS ALLOWED FOR THIS QUESTION. Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit. Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point. Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for which <math alttext="f of x" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is a real number. Functions <math alttext="f" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="g" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="h" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> are twice-differentiable functions with <math alttext="g of 2, equals, h of 2, which equals 4" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mi>h</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. The line <math alttext="y equals, 4 plus, two thirds times, open parenthesis, x minus 2, close parenthesis" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>+</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></mfrac><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is tangent to both the graph of <math alttext="g" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> at <math alttext="x equals 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> and the graph of <math alttext="h" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> at <math alttext="x equals 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. a) Find <math alttext="h prime of 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>.

b) Let <math alttext="a" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>a</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> be the function given by <math alttext="a, of x, equals, 3 times x cubed, times h of x " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>a</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msup><mi>h</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. Write an expression for <math alttext="a, prime of x" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>a</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. Find <math alttext="a, prime of 2 " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>a</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>.

c) The function <math alttext="h" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> satisfies <math alttext="h of x, equals, the fraction with numerator x squared, minus 4, and denominator 1 minus, open parenthesis, f of x, close parenthesis, cubed, end fraction" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>−</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>−</mo><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math> for <math alttext="x is not equal to 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>≠</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. It is known that <math alttext="the limit as x approaches 2, of, h of x" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><munder><mrow><mi>lim</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>→</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></munder><mi>h</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> can be evaluated using L’Hospital’s Rule. Use <math alttext="the limit as x approaches 2, of, h of x" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><munder><mrow><mi>lim</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>→</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></munder><mi>h</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> to find <math alttext="f of 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="f prime of 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. Show the work that leads to your answers.

d) It is known that <math alttext="g of x, is less than or equal to, h of x " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>≤</mo><mi>h</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> for <math alttext="1 less than x, less than 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo><</mo><mi>x</mi><mo><</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Let <math alttext="k" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> be a function satisfying <math alttext="g of x, is less than or equal to, k of x, is less than or equal to, h of x" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>≤</mo><mi>k</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>≤</mo><mi>h</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> for <math alttext="1 less than x, less than 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo><</mo><mi>x</mi><mo><</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Is <math alttext="k" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> continuous at <math alttext="x equals 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> ? Justify your answer.

topic.text: 1.8: Determining Limits Using the Squeeze Theorem

skill.text: Skill 1.D: Identify an appropriate mathematical rule or procedure based on the relationship between concepts (e.g., rate of change and accumulation) or processes (e.g., differentiation and its inverse process, anti-differentiation) to solve problems.
